buffer.translation[0].definitions[0].def: someone or something that protects one thing or person from being harmed by another
buffer.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Eastern Europe was important to Russia as a buffer against the West.
She often had to act as a buffer between father and son.
buffer.translation[0].definitions[1].def: one of the two special metal springs on the front or back of a train or at the end of a railway track, to take the shock if the train hits something
buffer.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a place in a computer’s memory for storing information temporarily
buffer.translation[0].definitions[3].def: an old man who is not good at managing things
buffer.translation[0].definitions[4].def: something used to polish a surface
buffer.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to reduce the bad effects of something
buffer.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Consumer spending is buffering the effects of the recession.
buffer.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if a computer buffers information, it holds it for a short while before using it
buffer.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a place in a computer’s memory for storing information temporarily
buffer.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Any data still in the file buffer is written to the file before the file is closed.
buffer.translation[2].definitions[1].def: something that protects something from unpleasant effects
buffer.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Many managers raised cash as a buffer against falling stocks last year, easing their overall losses.
